subtitle: chapter 42 last days with my guru guru
ji I am glad to find you alone this

master looked about the room as though

Master lowered his gaze Yogananda must I

Yogananda I love you always your answer

was he thinking of the shipboard

on Master spoke quietly his
is calm and quiet my heart was

sir the khumba MELAS convening this

my guru then fell into silence not

God has compassionately arranged that I
be distant from the scene
our party reached the Kumbha Mela on
January 23rd 1936 the surging crowd of
nearly 2 million persons was an
impressive sight even an overwhelming
one the peculiar genius of the Indian
people is the reverence innate in even
lowliest peasants for the worth of the
spirit and for the monks and sadhus who
are forsaken worldly ties to seek a
diviner Anchorage Impostors and
hypocrites there are indeed but India
respects all for the sake of a few who
illuminate the whole land with supernal
blessings Westerners who were viewing
the vast spectacle had a unique
opportunity to feel the pulse of the
land the spiritual order to which India
owes her conscious vitality before the
blows of time the first day was spent by
our group in sheer staring here were
countless bathers dipping in the holy
river for remission of sins there we saw
solemn rituals of worship yonder were
devotional offerings being strewn at the
dusty feet of saints a turn of our heads
and a line of elephants car pausing
whoresons and slow paced Raj Boonton
camels fill by or a quaint religious
parade of naked sadhus waving scepters
of gold and silver or flags and
streamers of silk and velvet anchorites
were
in cloth sat quietly little groups their
bodies besmirched with the ashes that
protect them from the heat and cold the
spiritual Iowa's vividly represented on
their foreheads by a single spot of
sandalwood paste shaven-headed Swami's
appeared by the thousands okra robed and
carrying their bamboo staff and begging
bowl their faces beamed with renunciants
peace as they walked about her held
philosophical discussions with disciples
here and there under the trees around
huge piles of burning logs were pretty
residues their hair braided and masks
and coils on the top of their head some
wore beard several feet in length curled
and tied in a knot they meditated
quietly or extended their hands and
blessing to the passing throng beggars
Maharaja's on elephants women in
multicolored saris their bangles and
anklets tinkling the cures with thin
arms held good testicle aloft Brahma
cherries carrying meditation elbow props
humbles sages who celebrity hid an inner
bliss
high above the din we heard the CSIs
summons of the temple bells on our
second male a day my companions and I
entered various ashrams and temporary
Hut's offering Pro noms to saintly
personage we received the blessing of
the leader of a Giri branch of the Swami
order a thin ascetical monk with eyes of
smiling fire our next visit took us to a
hermitage whose guru had observed for
the past nine years the vows of silence
in a strict fruitarian diet on the
central diocese in the ashram Hall said
a blind sadhu Prag la choc shoe
profoundly learned in the Shastras and
highly revered by all sects after I had
given a brief discourse in Hindi on
Vedanta our group left the peaceful
hermitage to greet a nearby Swami Krrish
Ananda a handsome monk whose rosy cheeks
and impressive shoulders reclining near
him was a tame lioness succumbing to the
monks spiritual charm not I am sure to
his powerful physique the jungle animal
refuses all meet in favor
rice and milk the Swami has taught the
tani Arab beast to utter ohm in a deep
attractive growl a cat devotee our next
encounter an interview with a learning
young sadhu is well described mr.
wrights
sparkly and travel diary we rode in the
forward across the low Ganges on a
creaking pontoon bridge crawling snake
light through the crowds and over narrow
twisting lanes passing the sight on the
river bank which Yogananda Zhi pointed
out to me as the meeting place of baba
ji and Sri Yukteswar Jai alighting from
a car a short time later we walked some
distance to the thickening smoke of the
Saudis fire and over the slippery sands
too rich a cluster of tiny very modest
mud and straw huts we halted in front of
one of these insignificant temporary
dwellings with a pygmy doorless entrance
the shelter of karapa tree a young
wandering sadhu noted for his
exceptional intelligence there he sat
cross-legged on a pile of straw his only
covering and incidentally his only
possession being an okra cloth draped
over his shoulders truly a divine face
smiled at us after he'd crawled on all
fours into the hut and pranaam dat the
feet of this enlightened soul while the
kerosene lantern at the entrance
flickered weird dancing shadows on the
thatched wall his face especially his
eyes and perfect teeth gleamed and
glistened although I was puzzled by the
Hindi his expression was very revealing
he was full of enthusiasm love spiritual
glory
no one could be mistaken as to his
greatness
imagine the happy life of one unattached
to the material world free of the
clothing problem free of food craving
never begging never touching cooked food
except on alternate days never carrying
a begging bowl free from all money
entanglement never handling money never
storing things away always trusting in
God free of transportation worries never
riding in vehicles but always walking on
the banks of the sacred rivers never
remaining one place longer than a week
in order to
avoid any growth of attachment such a
modest soul unusually learned in the
Vedas and possessing an MA degree and
the title of Shastri master of
scriptures from Banaras university a
sublime feeling pervaded me as I sat at
his feet it all seemed to be an answer
to my desire to see the real the ancient
India for he is a true representative of
this land the spiritual Giants I
questioned Carra Patri about his
wandering life don't you have any extra
clothes for winter no this is enough do
you care any books no I teach from
memory those people who wish to hear me
what else do you do I roam by the Ganges
at these quiet words I was overpowered
by yearning for the simplicity of his
life I remembered America and all the
responsibilities that lay in my
shoulders no yoga and I thought sadly
for a moment in this life roaming by the
Ganges is not for you after the sadhu
had told me a few of a spiritual
realizations I shot an abrupt question
are you giving these descriptions from
spiritual law or from inward experience
half from book learning he answered with
a straightforward smile and half from
experience
we sat happily awhile in meditative
silence after we had left his sacred
presence I said to mr. right he is a
king sitting on a throne of gold and
straw we had our dinner that night on
the mela ground under the stars eating
from leaf plates pinned together with
sticks dish washing in India are reduced
to a minimum two more days of the
fascinating khumba then Northwest along
the juma banks to Agra once again I
gazed in the Taj Mahal and memory tundra
stood by my side awed by the dreaming
marble then on the brindaban ashram of
swami Keshav ananda my object in seeking
over Kashyap ananda was connected with
his book I had never forgotten shuyak to

was taking every opportunity of
contacting direct disciples and
relatives of the
yoga avatar recording their

Larry Marcia portfolio began to swell I

prayed that I might be equal to my role
as biographer of the colossal guru
several of his disciples feared that in
a written account their master might be
belittle or misinterpreted one can
hardly do justice and cold words to life
of a divine incarnation pension on but a
try and once remarked to me other close

keep the yoga avatar hidden in their
hearts as a deathless preceptor
nevertheless mindful of Larry Marcia's
prediction about his biography I spared
no effort to secure and substantiate the

Keshav ananda greeted our party warmly
at brenda bond in his cattle jana peace
ashram an imposing brick building with
massive black pillars set in a beautiful
garden he ushered us once into a sitting
room adorned with an enlargement of
Larry Marcia's picture the Swami was
approaching the age of 19 but his
muscular body radiated strength and
health with long hair and snow white
beard eyes twinkling with joy he was a
veritable patriarchal embodiment I
informed him that I wanted to mention
his name in my book Gunn Indian masters
please tell me about your earlier life I
smiled entreatingly great Yogi's are
often uncommunicative Kashyap Ananda
made a gesture of humility there is a
little of external moment practically my
whole life has been spent in the
Himalayan solitudes traveling on foot
from one quiet cave to another for a
while I maintained a small ashram
outside Hardware surrounded on all sides
by groves of tall trees it was a
peaceful spot little visited by
travellers owing to the ubiquitous
present of Cobras kesha banana chuckled
later a Ganges flood washed away the
Hermitage in Cobras alike
my disciples then helped me to build
this brindaban ashram one of our party
asked the Swami how he had protected
himself against the Himalayan Tigers
ketchup Ananda shook his head in those
high spiritual altitude he said wild
beasts seldom Olustee Yogi's once in the
jungle I encountered a tiger
face-to-face at my sudden ejaculation
the animal was transfixed as though
turned to stone
again the Swami chuckled at his memories
occasionally I left my seclusion to
visit my guru in Banaras he used to joke
with me over my ceaseless travel in the
himalayan wilderness you have the mark
of wanderlust on your foot he told me
once I am glad that the sacred Himalayas
are extensive enough for you to
engrossed many times ketchup Ananda went
on both before and after his passing
Larry Marcia has appeared bodily before
me for him
no Himalayan height is inaccessible two
hours later he led us to a dining patio
I sighed in silent dismay another 15
course meal less than a year of Indian
hospitality and I had gained 50 pounds
yet it would have been considered the
height of rudeness to refuse any of the
dishes carefully prepared for the
endless banquets in my honor in India
nowhere else alas a well padded Swami is
considered a delightful sight after
dinner ketchup Ananda led me to a
secluded nook your arrival is not
unexpected he said I have a message for
you
I was surprised no one had known of my
plan to visit Ke$ha banana while roaming
last year in northern Himalayas near
bread juyeon the Swami continued I lost
my way shelter appeared in a spacious
cave which was empty though the embers
of a fire glowed in the hole in the
rocky floor wondering about the occupant
of this lonely retreat i sat near the
fire my gaze fixed on the sunlit
entrance to the cave Keshav Ananda I am
glad you are here these words came from
behind me I turned startled and was
dazzle of a whole Babaji
the great guru had materialized himself
in the recess of the cave overjoyed to
see him again after many years I
prostate admire his holy feet I called
you here baba ji went on that is why you
lost your way and were led to my
temporary abode in his cave it is a long
time since our last meeting I am pleased
to greet you once more the deathless
master blessed me with some words of

visit on this return to India many
matters connected with his guru and with
the surviving disciples of Larry will
keep Yogananda fully occupied tell him
then that I won't see him this time as
is eagerly hoping but I shall see him on
some other occasion I was deeply touched
to receive from Ke$ha bananas lips
this consoling promise from Baba ji a
certain hurt in my heart vanished I
grieve no longer that even as Sri
Yukteswar hinted Baba Jay did not appear
at the Kumbha Mela spending one night as

riding over the bridge of the Jamuna

of Vulcan in colour reflected below us
in the still waters the Jim Nabila by
memories of the child shri krishna here
he engaged with innocent sweetness in
his Leela's
with the gopis exemplifying the supernal

chooser in a few days our little group

Yukteswar I was disappointed to hear

in puri about 300 miles of the south
come to Puri ashram at once this
telegram was sent on March 8th by a
brother disciple - Atul Chandra Roy
Chowdhury one of the Masters Chile's in
Calcutta news of the message reached my
ears anguished at its implications
I dropped my knees and implored God that
my gurus life be spared as I was about
to leave father's home for the train a
divine voice spoke within do not go to
Puri tonight the prayer cannot be
granted Lord I said grief-stricken now
does not wish to engage with me in a tug
of war Puri whether I will have to deny
my incessant prayer for masters life
must he then depart for higher duties
thy behest in obedience to the inward
command I did not leave that night for
Puri the following evening I sat out for
the train on the way at seven o'clock a
black astral cloud suddenly covered the
sky later what a train roared towards
Puri a vision of Sri Yukteswar appeared
before me he was sitting very grave of
countenance with a light on each side
is it all over I lifted my arms
beseechingly he nodded then slowly
vanished as I stood on the Puri train
platform the following morning still
hoping against hope an unknown man
approached me have you heard that your
master is gone
he left me without another word I never
discovered who he was or how he had
known were to found me stunned I swayed
against the platform wall realizing that
in diverse ways my guru was trying to
convey to me the devastating news
seething with rebellion my soul was like
a volcano by the time I reached the Puri
Hermitage I was nearing collapse the
inner voice was tender in repeating ly
collect yourself be calm I entered the
ashram room where masters body
unimaginably lifelike was sitting the
Lotus posture a picture of health and
loveliness a short time before his
passing my guru had been slightly ill
with fever but before the day of his
ascension into the infinite his body had
become completely well no matter how
often I looked at his dear form I could
not realize that its life had departed
his skin was smooth and soft in his face
with a beautiful expression of
tranquility he had consciously
relinquished his body at the hour of
mystic summoning the lion of Bengal is
gone I cried in a daze
I conducted the solemn rites on March
10th Sri Yukteswar was buried with the
ancient rituals of the Swami in the
garden of his Puri ashram his disciples
later arrived from far and near to honor
their guru at a vernal equinox memorial
service the amrita bazar patrika
leading newspaper of calcutta carried
his picture in the following report the
death bandera ceremony from shrimp swami
sri yukteshwar Giri Maharaj aged 81 took
place at Pieria and March 21st many
disciples came down to Puri for the
rites one of the greatest expound errs
of the bhagavad-gita Swami Maharaj was a
great disciple of the yoga Raj
sri Shama Sharon lorry Masha
Banaras Swami Maharaj was the founder of
several regatta
satsanga centres in India and was the
great inspiration behind the yoga
movement which was carried to the west
by Swami Yogananda his principal
disciple
it was Sri Yukteswar Jay's prophetic
powers and deep realization that
inspired Swami Yogananda de cross the
oceans and spread in America the message
of the Masters of India his
interpretations the bhagavad-gita and
other scriptures testify to the depth of
three Yogeshwara G's command of the
philosophy both eastern and western and
remains as an eye opener for the unity
between orient and oxidant as he
believed in the unity of all religious
faiths Sri Yukteswar maharaj established
sadhu Sabu society of Saints with the
cooperation of leaders of various sects
and faiths for the in calculation of a
scientific spirit in religion at the
time of his demise he nominated Swami
Yogananda his successor as the president
of sadhu Sabha India is really poor
today for the passing of such a great
man may all fortunate enough to have
come near him in calculating themselves
the true spirit of India's culture and
sadhana which is personified in him I
returned to Calcutta
not trusting myself as yet to go to the
sern poor Hermitage with its sacred
memories I summoned Prafulla
Sri Yukteswar little disciple and
Serampore and made arrangements for him
to enter the rocchi school the morning
you left for the al-abaad Mela poor
fella told me master dropped heavily in
a davenport Yogananda is gone he cried
Yogananda is gone he added cryptically I
shall have to tell him some other way
he sat then for hours in silence my days
were filled with lectures classes
interviews and reunions with old friends
beneath the hollow smile and life of
Cesis activity a stream of black
brooding polluted the inn
River bliss which for so many years had
meandered under the sands of all my
perceptions where has that divine sage
gone I cried silently from the depths of
a tormented spirit no answer came it is
best that master has completed his union
with a cosmic beloved my mind assured me
he is eternally glowing in the minion of
deathlessness never again may you see
him in the Old Sarum poor match in my
heart lamented no longer may you bring
your friends to meet him or proudly say

mr. right made arrangements for our
party to sail from Bombay for the West
